API: String.format()

Explanation: This method formats the given string using the specified format. In this case, it's just formatting the string "Hello, World!" to be exactly that string.

API: String.join()
Code: String.join(", ", "Hello", "World");
Explanation: This method concatenates all the elements of the given iterable (in this case, an array of Strings) into a single string, using the specified delimiter (in this case, a comma and a space).

A: Yes, there are equivalent methods in Java.

API: String.format()
Code: String.format("%s", "Hello, World!");
Explanation: This method formats the given string using the specified format. In this case, it's just formatting the string "Hello, World!" to be exactly that string.

API: String.join()
Code: String.join(", ", "Hello", "World");
Explanation: This method concatenates all the elements of the given iterable (in this case, an array of Strings) into a single string, using the specified delimiter (in this case, a comma and a space).

In Java, you can use the String.join() method to replace C#'s String.Join(). The String.format() method can be used to replace C#'s String.Format().
